results.title: The Conversation
results.creator_credit: Francis Ford Coppola, Paramount Pictures and Zoetrope Studios
results.brief_description: Gene Hackman plays Harry Caul, an expert surveillance man, who during a routine wire-tapping job hears snatches of conversation which make him believe a young couple is in danger. The more Harry tries to discover the secret surrounding the couple, the more he descends into a nightmare of secrecy, betrayal and murder, all taking place amidst a world of moral ambivalence. Influenced by the Watergate scandals of the early 1970’s, “The Conversation” is a tense and excellently edited suspense thriller. It is also Coppola’s most anguished and personal film.

results.title: The Control revolution
results.creator_credit: Richard Moore, National Educational Television and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description: Explains how the development of the computer has made possible the automatic control of routine tasks in government, industry and business. Presents various computer systems ranging from data processing applications to mechanical control systems. Introduces basic concepts in business information systems including feedback, decision making processes and data modelling.

results.title: The Control of working capital (NP)
results.brief_description: Designed to explain the essentials of business finance to people without any financial background. Uses a dramatic format to explain how a cash crisis can be avoided by reducing working capital in four key areas: purchasing, manufacturing, sales, and credit control. Starring John Cleese and Ronnie Corbett and written by Antony Jay (of “Yes Prime Minister” fame). Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Conquered dream
results.creator_credit: Michael McKennirey, Richard Robinson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A documentary history of the exciting, sometimes ill-fated exploration of Canada’s Arctic, produced jointly by the British Broadcasting Corporation and the National Film Board of Canada. The film shows the challenge and the rewards of the far north and, from rare film footage, some of the exploits of the first and last men to run the gauntlet of the cold: Byrd’s flight; Stefansson’s sled journey; Captain Bernier’s explorations; and finally, the voyage of the U.S.S. Manhattan. Commentary written and spoken by Stanley Jackson.

results.title: The Closet = Le Placard [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Francis Veber, Alain Poire, TF1 Films productions, EFVE, Canal+ and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The Closet is a farcical French comedy from writer/director Francis Veber (The Dinner game, Les Fugitifs, The Birdcage). Francois Pignon (Daniel Auteuil) is an accountant in a rubber factory, where he is regarded as boring, insignificant, disposable and ‘unmanly’. Pignon, estranged from his ex-wife and teenage son, is about to be fired, an event that he regards as catastrophic. His response to his impending unemployment is attempted suicide until his new neighbour (Michel Aumont) talks him out of that plan and into another - if Pignon pretends he is gay the company will not fire him for fear of seeming homophobic. The effects on Pignon’s life, of his decision to come out of the closet, are enormous and ricochet into the lives of family and colleagues. “The Closet” explores notions of homophobia, machismo, discrimination, work place relationships and sexuality in a comedic manner. Stars some of France’s finest actors - Daniel Auteuil, Gerard Depardieu, Michele Laroque, Thierry Lhermitte and Jean Rochefort. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: The Confessional = Le Confessionnal
results.creator_credit: Robert Robert Lepage, Philippe Carcassonne, David Puttnam, Denise Robert, Cinea, Enigma Films and Cinemaginaire
results.brief_description: Past, present and the world of cinema merge in this unique and visually innovate thriller. Quebec, 1952, and the church is abuzz as master director Alfred Hitchcock (played by Ron Burrage) is in town to film “I Confess”. An equally gripping story is going on in the background - the elements echoing that of the plot, as 16 year old church worker, Rachel (Suzanne Clement), is with child to an unknown father, only a young priest knows the truth. Quebec, 1989 and Pierre (Lothaire Bluteau) returns home to attend the funeral of his father. During his stay Pierre vows to solve the mystery of the parentage of his half brother, Marc (Patrick Goyette)- Rachel’s son, a discontented rent boy and father of a young child. Pierre’s mission is not an easy one, as the secrets of the past and heredity cloud the situation and find resonance in the future. Like the plot of Hitchcock’s film, only one man holds the key to past and present that was disclosed to him in the confines of the confessional. In French with English subtitles.
